frameDefinitions: An Entity changes from a Prior_state to a Post_state in a sequence that follows a pre-defined plan, expectation, or model of change.

This frame consists of words that indicate that an Agent or a Cause affects the position of an Item on some scale (the Attribute) to change it from an initial value (Value_1) to an end value (Value_2).
A Wearer puts on an item of Clothing, which then occupies the Body_location.
An Arguer presents a Content, along with Support, to an Addressee.
This frame contains perception words whose Perceivers have perceptual experiences that they do not necessarily intend to.
An Agent, Actor, Entity, or Medium causes a Phenomenon to be perceived by a Perceiver.
frameExamples: Their offensive armament has <t>developed</t> from short range missiles to long-range ballistic weaponry in a relatively short period .
The company is <t>raising</t> the final dividend from 4.34p to 4.57p, to boost the total by 5.3 percent to 6.36p.
You didn't have to <t>dress</t> like a pirate to impress me. INI
Jan <t>argued</t> that the evidence was inadmissable.
Abashed, realising that he had <t>overheard</t> her conversation with Victoria, Sheeley didn't try to make excuses.
listRoleDefinitions: The object that undergoes change.
The time at which the progress occurs.
The location where the Progress occurs.
The person who causes an entity (Item) to change its positon on a scale with respect to some property (Variable).
The scale along which the <fen>Item</fen> ranges in value.
The entity whose position along a scale is being changed.
The force that causes the change.
When the event occurs.
The location where the <fen>Agent</fen> changes the value of an <fen>Attribute</fen>.
The individual that puts <fen>Clothing</fen> on their body.
<fen>Clothing</fen> is used for the item of clothing that the <fen>Wearer</fen> ends up wearing.
The time when the <fen>Wearer</fen> puts an item of <fen>Clothing</fen> on.
The <fen>Place</fen> indicates where the Donning occurs.

The <fen>Arguer</fen> wants the <fen>Addressee</fen> to entertain the <fen>Content</fen>, which can be a proposition to be believed or a course of action to be taken, based on the <fen>Support</fen> presented.
The <fen>Arguer</fen> presents the <fen>Content</fen> before the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The Time at which an <fen>Arguer</fen> makes an argument for the <fen>Content</fen>.
This role identifies the location where an argument is made by an <fen>Arguer</fen>.
This role is the being who has a perceptual experience, not necessarily on purpose. It is typically expressed as an External Argument.
This role is the entity or phenomenon that the perceiver experiences with his or her senses. It is typically expressed as Object with verbs.
The <fen>Body_part</fen> is the location on the <fen>Perceiver_passive</fen>'s body where the perceptual experience  takes place.  It is typically expressed in a PP.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the <fen>Perceiver_passive</fen> or the <fen>Body_part</fen> perceives the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
The general location within which the act of perception takes place.
The <fen>Agent</fen> intentionally creates a situation in which the <fen>Perceiver</fen> observes or experiences the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
The <fen>Phenomenon</fen> is an entity or idea that is perceived by the <fen>Perceiver</fen>.
The <fen>Perceiver</fen> is made to have a perceptual experience by the <fen>Agent</fen>.
An <fen>Actor</fen> is a sentient being who is exhibiting, possibly uninintentionally, some <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
An object that has some association with a <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
The <fen>Medium</fen> through which a <fen>Phenomenon</fen> is expressed.
When the event occurs.
The location where the <fen>Agent</fen> causes the perception of the <fen>Perceiver</fen>.
listRoleExamples: Advances <fex>in marketing techniques</fex> have since rendered it obsolete.
<fex>When</fex> did the X-wing progress beyond the drawing board?
<fex>The rain</fex> increased the river's flow rate to an astonishing million gallons per second.
As a result, they raised prices <fex>in Peoria</fex>.
She had put the dress on <fex>this morning</fex> expecting it to be sunny.
Jan argued <fex>that the evidence was inadmissable</fex>.
<fex>Jan</fex> argued that the evidence was inadmissable.
The government argued <fex>in August</fex> that the prisoners should not be released
The young men will be arguing their policies <fex>in the school auditorium</fex>.
<fex>The waiter</fex> smelled something foul in the kitchen.
The waiter smelled <fex>something foul</fex> in the kitchen.
Marlow felt something cold and hard <fex>against the back of his neck</fex>.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: Plato at the Googleplex: Why Philosophy Won't Go Away
